words.example: Der Mann liest. Die Frau schläft. Das Kind spielt.
words.example_translation: The man reads. The woman sleeps. The child plays.
words.rule: Nominative case shows the subject (who/what does the action)
words.notes: This is the 'dictionary form' of nouns

words.example: der/ein Mann, die/eine Frau, das/ein Kind
words.example_translation: the/a man, the/a woman, the/a child
words.rule: Nominative articles: der/die/das, ein/eine/ein
words.notes: Same as dictionary form you've learned

words.example: Ich bin ein Student. Das ist eine Lehrerin.
words.example_translation: I am a student. That is a teacher.
words.rule: After 'sein' (to be), use nominative case
words.notes: Both sides of 'sein' are nominative

words.example: Wer ist das? Was ist das?
words.example_translation: Who is that? What is that?
words.rule: Wer (who) and was (what) are nominative question words
words.notes: These ask about the subject

words.example: Ich lese den Brief. Sie kauft eine Blume.
words.example_translation: I read the letter. She buys a flower.
words.rule: Accusative case shows the direct object (who/what receives the action)
words.notes: Answers the question 'wen?' (who) or 'was?' (what)

words.english: Only masculine articles change in accusative
words.example: den Mann, einen Mann (but: die Frau, das Kind unchanged)
words.example_translation: the man, a man (but: the woman, the child unchanged)
words.rule: Masculine: der→den, ein→einen. Feminine/neuter unchanged
words.notes: Only masculine changes in accusative!

words.example: haben, essen, trinken, kaufen, lesen, sehen
words.example_translation: to have, eat, drink, buy, read, see
words.rule: Most transitive verbs take accusative objects
words.notes: These are 'doing' verbs that affect something

words.example: Wen siehst du? Was isst du?
words.example_translation: Who do you see? What do you eat?
words.rule: Wen (who) for people, was (what) for things in accusative
words.notes: Wen is accusative form of wer

words.example: Ich sehe den Hund. Er kauft einen Apfel.
words.example_translation: I see the dog. He buys an apple.
words.rule: Remember: masculine changes der→den, ein→einen
words.notes: Feminine and neuter don't change

words.example: Sie liest den Brief, die Zeitung und das Buch.
words.example_translation: She reads the letter, the newspaper and the book.
words.rule: Only masculine article changes in accusative
words.pattern: den Brief(m), die Zeitung(f), das Buch(n)
words.notes: Good way to practice all three genders

words.example: Ich warte einen Tag. Sie arbeitet eine Stunde.
words.example_translation: I wait one day. She works one hour.
words.rule: Duration of time uses accusative case
words.notes: How long something takes

words.example: Der Mann sieht den Mann. (Two different men!)
words.example_translation: The man sees the man. (Two different men!)
words.rule: Subject (nominative) does action to object (accusative)
words.notes: Case endings show who does what to whom

words.example: Ich verstehe nicht. Das ist nicht gut.
words.example_translation: I don't understand. That is not good.
words.rule: 'Nicht' negates verbs, adjectives, and adverbs
words.notes: General negation word

words.example: Ich arbeite nicht. Ich gehe nicht nach Hause.
words.example_translation: I don't work. I'm not going home.
words.rule: 'Nicht' usually comes at the end, or before prepositional phrases
words.notes: End position is safest for beginners

words.example: Das Haus ist nicht groß. Er läuft nicht schnell.
words.example_translation: The house is not big. He doesn't run fast.
words.rule: 'Nicht' comes directly before adjectives and adverbs
words.notes: This position is fixed

words.example: Verstehst du nicht? Ist das nicht schön?
words.example_translation: Don't you understand? Isn't that beautiful?
words.rule: 'Nicht' follows same position rules in questions
words.notes: Often expects 'yes' as answer in German

words.example: Das ist kein Hund. Ich habe keine Zeit.
words.example_translation: That is not a dog. I have no time.
words.rule: 'Kein' negates nouns that would use 'ein' or no article
words.notes: Replaces ein/eine/ein in negative sentences

words.example: Nominative: kein/keine/kein, Accusative: keinen/keine/kein
words.example_translation: No man/woman/child (subject/object)
words.rule: 'Kein' follows same pattern as 'ein' but has plural form
words.pattern: Like ein + plural: keine (for all genders)
words.notes: Unlike 'ein', 'kein' has a plural form

words.example: Ich habe kein Auto. (not: nicht ein Auto) / Das ist nicht mein Auto.
words.example_translation: I don't have a car. / That is not my car.
words.rule: Use 'kein' with indefinite nouns, 'nicht' with definite nouns
words.pattern: kein + indefinite noun, nicht + definite noun
words.notes: Kein = no/not a, nicht = not the

words.example: Ich habe keine Kinder. Wir haben keine Probleme.
words.example_translation: I have no children. We have no problems.
words.rule: 'Keine' is used for all plural nouns (any gender)
words.notes: Keine works for all plural, regardless of original gender

words.example: mein Vater, meine Mutter, mein Kind
words.example_translation: my father, my mother, my child
words.rule: 'Mein' changes like 'ein' to match the possessed noun
words.notes: Changes based on the thing owned, not the owner

words.example: dein Buch, deine Tasche, dein Auto
words.example_translation: your book, your bag, your car
words.rule: 'Dein' follows same pattern as 'mein'
words.notes: Used with people you call 'du'

words.example: sein Haus (his house), ihr Haus (her house)
words.example_translation: his house, her house
words.rule: 'Sein' (his) and 'ihr' (her) change like 'ein'
words.notes: Sein=his, ihr=her (don't confuse with Sie/ihr)

words.example: unser Lehrer, euer Lehrer
words.example_translation: our teacher, your (plural) teacher
words.rule: 'Unser' and 'euer' also follow 'ein' pattern
words.notes: Euer often drops middle -e-: eur-

words.example: Mein Hund ist groß. Deine Katze schläft.
words.example_translation: My dog is big. Your cat sleeps.
words.rule: Possessives in nominative: mein/meine/mein, etc.
words.notes: Same as basic forms you learned

words.example: Ich sehe meinen Hund. Du liest dein Buch.
words.example_translation: I see my dog. You read your book.
words.rule: Masculine possessives add -en in accusative
words.notes: Only masculine forms change, like with 'ein'→'einen'

words.example: Ich nehme mein Buch. (not: das Buch)
words.example_translation: I take my book. (not: the book)
words.rule: Use possessive to show ownership, not definite article
words.pattern: possessive replaces der/die/das when showing ownership
words.notes: Can't use both possessive AND article together

words.example: meine Familie, dein Freund, unser Haus, ihre Arbeit
words.example_translation: my family, your friend, our house, her work
words.rule: Possessives are very common in everyday German
words.notes: Practice these common combinations
